title: Ezekiel Chapter 36 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 36 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 36 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 36.

questions.question: To whom does the Lord command Ezekiel to prophesy in Ezekiel 36:1?
options: The mountains of Israel
The people of Jerusalem
The rivers of Babylon
The children of Edom
questions.correctAnswer: The mountains of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:1 states, '...prophesy unto the mountains of Israel...'

questions.question: What did the enemy say concerning the land in Ezekiel 36:2?
options: Aha, even the ancient high places are ours
The land will never be restored
The people have forgotten God
The rivers are dry and cursed
questions.correctAnswer: Aha, even the ancient high places are ours
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:2 records the enemy saying, 'Aha, even the ancient high places are ours in possession.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 36:3, what did the enemy do to the land of Israel?
options: Made it desolate and swallowed it up
Built great cities
Protected it from invaders
Blessed it with abundance
questions.correctAnswer: Made it desolate and swallowed it up
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:3 says they 'have made you desolate, and swallowed you up on every side.'

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as receiving the word of the LORD in Ezekiel 36:4?
options: Mountains
Hills
Rivers
Oceans
questions.correctAnswer: Oceans
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:4 mentions mountains, hills, rivers, valleys, desolate wastes, and cities but not oceans.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 36:5, who did God say had appointed His land into their possession?
options: The residue of the heathen and all Idumea
The house of Israel
The children of Judah
The priests of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The residue of the heathen and all Idumea
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:5 states that the residue of the heathen and all Idumea had appointed God's land into their possession.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 36:7 says the heathen around Israel will bear their shame.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:7 states, 'Surely the heathen that are about you, they shall bear their shame.'

questions.question: What will the mountains of Israel do according to Ezekiel 36:8?
options: Shoot forth branches and yield fruit
Remain desolate forever
Be destroyed by fire
Become dry and barren
questions.correctAnswer: Shoot forth branches and yield fruit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:8 promises the mountains will 'shoot forth your branches, and yield your fruit to my people of Israel.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 36:10, what will happen to the cities in Israel?
options: They shall be inhabited and the wastes shall be built
They shall be burned down
They shall remain empty
They shall be given to the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be inhabited and the wastes shall be built
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:10 states the cities shall be inhabited and the wastes shall be builded.

questions.question: What is the reason God gives for restoring Israel according to Ezekiel 36:22?
options: For His holy name’s sake which was profaned
For Israel's righteousness
For the sake of the prophets
For the sake of the priests
questions.correctAnswer: For His holy name’s sake which was profaned
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:22 says restoration is not for Israel’s sake but for God’s holy name's sake.

questions.question: What will God sprinkle upon the house of Israel to cleanse them, as mentioned in Ezekiel 36:25?
options: Clean water
Oil
Fire
Wine
questions.correctAnswer: Clean water
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:25 states, 'Then will I sprinkle clean water upon you, and ye shall be clean.'

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 36:27 says God will put His spirit within the people and cause them to walk in His statutes.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:27 states God will put His spirit within them and make them follow His statutes.

questions.question: What kind of heart will God give according to Ezekiel 36:26?
options: A heart of flesh
A stony heart
A heart of gold
A heart of iron
questions.correctAnswer: A heart of flesh
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26 says God will take away the stony heart and give a heart of flesh.

questions.question: What will the land become according to Ezekiel 36:35?
options: Like the garden of Eden
A desert
A battlefield
A wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Like the garden of Eden
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:35 says the desolate land will become like the garden of Eden.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 36:31, the people will remember their evil ways and be ashamed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:31 states they shall remember their evil ways and loathe themselves.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I will take you from among the ______, and gather you out of all countries.'
options: heathen
nations
enemies
cities
questions.correctAnswer: heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:24 states, 'For I will take you from among the heathen, and gather you out of all countries.'

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 36 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 36 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels ashamed because of past sins and failures. Based on Ezekiel 36, what biblical truth would you share about God’s purpose in restoration?
options: God restores not for their sakes but for His holy name’s sake
God restores only those who are without sin
God restores so they can earn His favor by works
God restores because people deserve it
questions.correctAnswer: God restores not for their sakes but for His holy name’s sake
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:22-23 and 32 clearly state that God acts to sanctify His name, not primarily for Israel’s sake, teaching us humility and gratitude in restoration.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 teach us about God’s faithfulness in times of spiritual barrenness or desolation?
options: God promises to multiply men and animals and rebuild wastelands
God will leave the desolate land as it is
God punishes the land permanently for sin
God only restores if the people perform sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to multiply men and animals and rebuild wastelands
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 and 33-36 describe God’s promise to cause the land to be tilled and inhabited again, showing His faithfulness and power to restore.

questions.question: A believer struggling with temptation asks how God’s Spirit helps in obedience. What does Ezekiel 36 teach about this?
options: God will put His Spirit within them and enable them to walk in His statutes
God expects them to obey without help
Obedience is optional and not important
God punishes disobedience without offering help
questions.correctAnswer: God will put His Spirit within them and enable them to walk in His statutes
questions.explanation: Verse 27 states God will put His Spirit within His people to enable obedience, teaching reliance on divine help in spiritual discipline.

questions.question: What practical lesson about forgiveness and cleansing can be drawn from Ezekiel 36?
options: God will sprinkle clean water and cleanse from filthiness and idols
People must cleanse themselves without God’s help
Forgiveness is limited to a select few
Cleansing means ignoring past sins
questions.correctAnswer: God will sprinkle clean water and cleanse from filthiness and idols
questions.explanation: Verse 25 highlights God’s role in cleansing, illustrating the importance of divine forgiveness and spiritual renewal in Christian life.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 encourage believers to respond to past sins and failures?
options: To remember their evil ways and loathe themselves for iniquities
To deny and ignore their past
To blame others for their sins
To justify their wrongdoings
questions.correctAnswer: To remember their evil ways and loathe themselves for iniquities
questions.explanation: Verse 31 instructs self-reflection and repentance, teaching humility and sincere remorse as part of spiritual growth.

questions.question: A believer wonders about God’s promises regarding provision and blessing. What does Ezekiel 36 say about this?
options: God will increase the corn, fruit, and prevent famine
God’s provision is uncertain and unpredictable
Provision depends solely on human effort
Blessings are only spiritual, not physical
questions.correctAnswer: God will increase the corn, fruit, and prevent famine
questions.explanation: Verses 29-30 promise physical blessings and provision, encouraging trust and gratitude for God’s sustaining care.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 teach about God’s justice toward hostile nations around Israel?
options: God will cause surrounding nations to bear their shame
God ignores the actions of hostile nations
God rewards hostile nations
God tolerates their oppression forever
questions.correctAnswer: God will cause surrounding nations to bear their shame
questions.explanation: Verse 7 declares that nations who oppressed Israel will bear shame, showing God’s justice and vindication for His people.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 36, God’s restoration of Israel will cause them to be a reproach among the nations again.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 affirm that Israel will no longer be a reproach or bear the shame of the nations, showing God’s restoration removes disgrace.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 36 teaches that God’s forgiveness and renewal depend on Israel’s works alone.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes God’s initiative and mercy (verses 22-23, 26-27), showing forgiveness and renewal are acts of divine grace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 36 teaches that God will give a new _____ and a new spirit within His people.
options: heart
land
name
judgment
questions.correctAnswer: heart
questions.explanation: Verse 26 states God will give a new heart and a new spirit, symbolizing spiritual renewal and transformation.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged about fruitfulness in service. How does Ezekiel 36 encourage perseverance and trust in God’s blessing?
options: God will cause the land to yield fruit and multiply men and beasts
Fruitfulness depends only on human effort
Discouragement means failure in faith
God withholds blessing for discipline
questions.correctAnswer: God will cause the land to yield fruit and multiply men and beasts
questions.explanation: Verses 8-11 promise fruitfulness and multiplication, encouraging trust in God’s power to bless faithful service.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 instruct believers on humility regarding their restoration and blessings?
options: They should be ashamed and confounded for their own ways
They should boast of their achievements
They should ignore their past sins
They should blame others for their failures
questions.correctAnswer: They should be ashamed and confounded for their own ways
questions.explanation: Verse 32 instructs Israel to be humble and remorseful, recognizing that blessings are not earned but God’s grace.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 36 reveal about the role of God’s Spirit in a believer’s daily walk?
options: God’s Spirit enables obedience to statutes and judgments
God’s Spirit is optional for obedience
Believers can obey without the Spirit
The Spirit only convicts but does not empower
questions.correctAnswer: God’s Spirit enables obedience to statutes and judgments
questions.explanation: Verse 27 teaches that God’s Spirit actively empowers believers to obey His laws, emphasizing reliance on divine guidance.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 36, what is the significance of God saying He will bring His people back to their land?
options: It symbolizes restoration, inheritance, and God’s covenant faithfulness
It means only physical relocation without spiritual change
It is a punishment for sin
It is dependent on human military power
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes restoration, inheritance, and God’s covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verses 24 and 28 show God gathering His people back as an act of covenant renewal and blessing, encouraging hope and trust.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 teach about God’s concern for His holy name among the nations?
options: God acts to sanctify His name because it was profaned by Israel
God ignores His reputation among the nations
God’s name is only relevant to Israel internally
God punishes Israel without regard for His name
questions.correctAnswer: God acts to sanctify His name because it was profaned by Israel
questions.explanation: Verses 21-23 reveal God’s motivation to restore Israel is to honor His holy name among the nations, teaching reverence and accountability.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 36 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 36.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 36, what is the significance of God promising to give Israel 'a new heart' and 'a new spirit'?
options: It symbolizes a complete internal transformation and renewal of the covenant people.
It refers to a political alliance with neighboring nations.
It indicates physical restoration of the land only.
It is a metaphor for Israel gaining military strength.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a complete internal transformation and renewal of the covenant people.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26 speaks of God taking away the 'stony heart' and giving a 'heart of flesh,' indicating a profound spiritual renewal beyond just physical restoration.

questions.question: Which phrase in Ezekiel 36 reflects the theme of God's jealousy and fury as a response to the desolation caused by heathen nations?
options: "Surely in the fire of my jealousy have I spoken against the residue of the heathen"
"I will multiply men upon you, all the house of Israel"
"Then shall ye remember your own evil ways"
"I will sprinkle clean water upon you"
questions.correctAnswer: "Surely in the fire of my jealousy have I spoken against the residue of the heathen"
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:5 explicitly declares God's jealousy and fury against the heathen who have taken possession of His land, expressing divine zeal for His covenant people.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 36 portrays the restoration of Israel as primarily a physical rebuilding of cities and land with no spiritual implications.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While physical restoration is emphasized (Ezekiel 36:33-35), the chapter also stresses spiritual renewal, such as giving a new heart and spirit (Ezekiel 36:26-27).

questions.question: The phrase 'mountains of Israel' in Ezekiel 36 is a literary device that primarily serves to:
options: Personify the land as a witness and participant in Israel's restoration.
Represent the enemies surrounding Israel.
Describe the agricultural fertility exclusively.
Refer to literal mountains used for pagan worship.
questions.correctAnswer: Personify the land as a witness and participant in Israel's restoration.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:1-4 addresses the mountains directly, a form of personification that emphasizes the land's integral role in the prophetic message and restoration.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 connect with the broader biblical theme of God's holy name and reputation among the nations?
options: God acts to sanctify His name because Israel profaned it among the heathen.
God ignores His name and focuses only on Israel's actions.
The name of God is not mentioned in this chapter.
God's name is only restored after Israel conquers neighboring nations.
questions.correctAnswer: God acts to sanctify His name because Israel profaned it among the heathen.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:21-23 explains that God's restoration of Israel is motivated by the desire to sanctify His name, which was profaned by Israel's disobedience among the nations.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 36, God promises to cleanse Israel 'from all your _____, and from all your idols'.
options: filthiness
enemies
sins
desolations
questions.correctAnswer: filthiness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:25 states God will sprinkle clean water to cleanse Israel from all their filthiness and idols, indicating ritual and moral purification.

questions.question: Which historical context best explains the prophet's depiction of Israel's scattering among heathen nations in Ezekiel 36?
options: The Babylonian exile and dispersion of the Jewish people.
The conquest of Canaan by Joshua.
The Assyrian captivity of the northern kingdom.
The Roman destruction of Jerusalem in 70 AD.
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and dispersion of the Jewish people.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:19 references scattering among heathen nations, which corresponds historically to the Babylonian exile during Ezekiel's prophetic ministry.

questions.question: Ezekiel 36:27 states, 'I will put my spirit within you, and cause you to walk in my statutes.' This is a foreshadowing of which New Testament concept?
options: The indwelling of the Holy Spirit empowering believers to obey God.
The giving of the Ten Commandments on Mount Sinai.
The establishment of the Davidic monarchy.
The destruction of the temple in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: The indwelling of the Holy Spirit empowering believers to obey God.
questions.explanation: This verse anticipates the Christian doctrine of the Holy Spirit's role in enabling believers to follow God's law, a key theme in the New Testament (e.g., Acts 2).

questions.question: What is the primary authorial intent behind the repeated address to the 'mountains of Israel' and the 'land' throughout Ezekiel 36?
options: To emphasize the integral restoration of the land as part of Israel’s covenant identity.
To warn the mountains about incoming judgment.
To predict future geological events.
To contrast Israel's land with foreign territories.
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize the integral restoration of the land as part of Israel’s covenant identity.
questions.explanation: The chapter’s focus on land personification underscores its role as a covenant sign, with restoration symbolizing God's faithfulness (Ezekiel 36:8-12).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 36, why does God declare that He will act to restore Israel, 'not for your sakes, O house of Israel, but for mine holy name's sake'?
options: Because Israel profaned God's name among the nations, and God desires to sanctify it.
Because Israel had perfect obedience and deserved restoration.
Because God wants to punish the nations surrounding Israel.
Because Israel asked God with many sacrifices.
questions.correctAnswer: Because Israel profaned God's name among the nations, and God desires to sanctify it.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:22 reveals God's restoration is motivated by His desire to uphold His holy name, which Israel had profaned among the heathen.

questions.question: Which Old Testament parallel best aligns with the theme of God 'sprinkling clean water' to cleanse Israel in Ezekiel 36:25?
options: The ritual cleansing and purification laws in Leviticus.
The crossing of the Red Sea in Exodus.
The building of the Tabernacle in Exodus 25.
The Davidic covenant in 2 Samuel.
questions.correctAnswer: The ritual cleansing and purification laws in Leviticus.
questions.explanation: The sprinkling of clean water reflects purification rites found in Leviticus, symbolizing moral and ceremonial cleansing (Ezekiel 36:25).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 use the imagery of agricultural abundance and fruitfulness in describing Israel's restoration?
options: To symbolize the prosperity and blessing that will result from God's renewal.
To describe new farming techniques introduced by Israel.
To predict a literal return of all animal species.
To indicate a prophecy about foreign nations' wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: To symbolize the prosperity and blessing that will result from God's renewal.
questions.explanation: Verses like Ezekiel 36:8-11 and 29-30 use agricultural imagery to depict the flourishing of Israel as a result of divine blessing and restoration.

questions.question: What is the significance of the statement in Ezekiel 36:20 that Israel 'profaned my holy name' among the heathen?
options: Israel's disobedience caused God's reputation to be tarnished among the nations.
Israel invented new gods to replace Yahweh.
Israel was praised by the heathen for their faithfulness.
Israel conquered the heathen and took their land.
questions.correctAnswer: Israel's disobedience caused God's reputation to be tarnished among the nations.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:20 shows that Israel's exile and misconduct led to a dishonoring of God's name, motivating His restoration plan.

questions.question: True or False: The rebuilding of cities and tilled land in Ezekiel 36 serves as a sign to the surrounding nations of God's power and faithfulness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:35-36 describes how the restored land and cities will be recognized by the heathen as evidence of the LORD’s power and fulfillment of His word.

questions.question: What Hebrew literary device is prominently employed in Ezekiel 36:1-4 through the direct address to mountains, hills, rivers, and valleys?
options: Personification, giving the land human attributes.
Hyperbole, exaggerating the land’s desolation.
Chiasm, a symmetrical literary structure.
Parable, a symbolic story with a moral.
questions.correctAnswer: Personification, giving the land human attributes.
questions.explanation: The prophet addresses geographical features as if they can hear and respond, a personification that intensifies the message (Ezekiel 36:1-4).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 36 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 36 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does God declare He will do to the mountains and land of Israel in Ezekiel 36?
options: They shall shoot forth branches and yield fruit for His people
They shall remain desolate as a punishment
They shall be given to the heathen as a possession
They shall be destroyed by fire
questions.correctAnswer: They shall shoot forth branches and yield fruit for His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:8 states that the mountains of Israel will shoot forth branches and yield fruit for His people. This imagery reflects restoration and blessing, consistent with God's promises to renew and bless His covenant people (cf. Isaiah 27:6; Jeremiah 31:12; Joel 2:22; Zechariah 8:12).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 36, why does God declare that He acts to sanctify His holy name among the nations?
options: Not for Israel's sake but for His holy name's sake
Because Israel has been faithful
To punish the nations
To establish a new covenant with the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Not for Israel's sake but for His holy name's sake
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:22-23 reveals God acts to sanctify His holy name, which was profaned by Israel among the nations. This underscores God's self-glorification and faithfulness to His covenant promises regardless of Israel's unfaithfulness, aligning with Scripture that God acts for His own glory (cf. Romans 9:15-16; Ezekiel 20:9; Isaiah 48:9-11; Psalm 23:3).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: God promises in Ezekiel 36 that He will ___ clean water upon the people of Israel to cleanse them from all their filthiness.
options: sprinkle
pour
wash
flow
questions.correctAnswer: sprinkle
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:25 states that God will sprinkle clean water upon Israel to cleanse them from filth and idols. This is a metaphor for spiritual cleansing, paralleling New Testament baptismal imagery and purification (cf. Hebrews 10:22; Titus 3:5; John 3:5; Zechariah 13:1).

questions.question: What transformation does God promise to give the people of Israel in Ezekiel 36:26?
options: A new heart and a new spirit
A renewed land and abundant crops
A mighty army and great power
A river flowing from the temple
questions.correctAnswer: A new heart and a new spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26 promises a new heart and new spirit, replacing the stony heart with a heart of flesh. This signifies internal renewal by God’s Spirit, a foundational doctrine of regeneration (cf. Jeremiah 31:33; John 3:6-8; 2 Corinthians 5:17; Ezekiel 11:19).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 describe the role of the Spirit in the life of the renewed Israel?
options: The Spirit will be put within them to enable obedience to God's statutes
The Spirit will lead them into battle against the nations
The Spirit will cause them to build the temple
The Spirit will bring wealth and political power
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit will be put within them to enable obedience to God's statutes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:27 states God will put His Spirit within His people so they walk in His statutes and keep His judgments. This highlights the Spirit’s role in sanctification and empowerment for righteous living (cf. Joel 2:28-29; Romans 8:4; Galatians 5:16; John 14:26).

questions.question: What was the spiritual condition of Israel when they dwelt in their own land, according to Ezekiel 36?
options: They defiled the land by their way and doings
They were faithful and obedient to God
They worshiped God alone without idolatry
They prospered and multiplied without sin
questions.correctAnswer: They defiled the land by their way and doings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:17 describes Israel defiling the land by their ways and doings, likening it to the uncleanness of a removed woman, symbolizing impurity and sin. This reflects human sinfulness and its consequences on creation (cf. Numbers 35:33; Leviticus 18:24-30; Romans 3:23; Isaiah 1:4).

questions.question: What was the consequence of Israel's sinful actions on God's holy name among the nations?
options: God’s holy name was profaned among the heathen
God’s name was glorified by their repentance
The nations acknowledged God’s faithfulness
God’s name was forgotten among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holy name was profaned among the heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:20-21 explains that Israel profaned God's holy name among the heathen where they were scattered because of their disobedience. This highlights the corporate impact of sin on God's reputation (cf. Leviticus 18:21; Psalm 79:9; Isaiah 52:5; Romans 2:24).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the nature of Israel's restoration as portrayed in Ezekiel 36?
options: A spiritual and physical restoration including cleansing, new heart, and inhabited cities
A purely physical return without spiritual change
A temporary restoration followed by judgment
A restoration only for the elders and priests
questions.correctAnswer: A spiritual and physical restoration including cleansing, new heart, and inhabited cities
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36 presents a comprehensive restoration: God cleanses Israel (v. 25), gives a new heart and spirit (v. 26), and causes cities to be rebuilt and inhabited (v. 33-35). This is both spiritual renewal and physical restoration (cf. Jeremiah 31:33-34; Isaiah 44:3-5; Acts 3:19-21; Revelation 21:1-4).

questions.question: What does God say about the reproach and shame Israel experienced among the nations?
options: They will no longer bear the reproach or shame
They will continue to be shamed forever
They must endure shame until the Messiah comes
The shame will be transferred to the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: They will no longer bear the reproach or shame
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:14-15 promises that Israel will no longer devour men or bear shame among the nations. This assures a future removal of disgrace, consistent with God's redemption and vindication of His people (cf. Isaiah 54:4; Zephaniah 3:19; Romans 8:18; 2 Corinthians 4:17).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 depict the increase and blessing upon the land and people of Israel?
options: Multiplying men and beasts, increasing fruit and crops
Only spiritual blessings without material increase
A few survivors living in tents
The land remaining barren but the people prosperous
questions.correctAnswer: Multiplying men and beasts, increasing fruit and crops
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:10-11 and 29-30 describe God multiplying men and beasts and increasing crops and fruitfulness as part of restoration. This reflects God's providential blessing over His creation and covenant people (cf. Deuteronomy 28:11-12; Psalm 65:9-13; Joel 2:21-24; Matthew 6:26).

questions.question: Ezekiel 36:24 describes God gathering Israel from the nations. What theological theme does this express?
options: The theme of divine regathering and covenant restoration
The theme of final judgment without restoration
The theme of universal salvation without distinction
The theme of Israel’s permanent exile
questions.correctAnswer: The theme of divine regathering and covenant restoration
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:24’s promise to gather Israel from all countries highlights God's covenant faithfulness and the eschatological regathering of His people (cf. Isaiah 11:11-12; Jeremiah 23:3; Romans 11:26; Revelation 7:9). It is a key motif in biblical eschatology.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 36, what is the significance of God giving Israel a 'heart of flesh' instead of a 'stony heart'?
options: It signifies inner spiritual renewal and responsiveness to God
It means they will have stronger physical bodies
It indicates a political transformation
It symbolizes a return to idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies inner spiritual renewal and responsiveness to God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26 uses the metaphor of replacing a stony heart with a heart of flesh to represent spiritual renewal and the ability to obey God. This aligns with the biblical doctrine of regeneration by the Spirit (cf. Ezekiel 11:19; Jeremiah 31:33; John 14:15; 2 Corinthians 3:3).

questions.question: What is the reason given in Ezekiel 36 for Israel’s scattering among the nations?
options: Because of their bloodshed and idolatry defiling the land
Because God wanted to bless other nations
Because they refused to build the temple
Because they wished to explore new lands
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their bloodshed and idolatry defiling the land
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:18-19 states Israel was scattered among the nations due to their bloodshed and idolatry which polluted the land. The scattering is a judgment for covenant unfaithfulness (cf. Deuteronomy 28:64; Jeremiah 9:16; Hosea 9:17; Acts 7:42-43).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 36 say about the future of the cities and desolate land of Israel?
options: The cities will be rebuilt and the desolate land will be tilled and inhabited
The cities will remain desolate permanently
The cities will be destroyed by fire
The land will become a wilderness for animals only
questions.correctAnswer: The cities will be rebuilt and the desolate land will be tilled and inhabited
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:33-35 promises the cities will be rebuilt and the desolate land will be cultivated and inhabited, symbolizing restoration and blessing (cf. Isaiah 61:4; Nehemiah 2:17-18; Jeremiah 31:38-40; Luke 1:32-33).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 36 describe the attitude Israel will have toward their former sins after restoration?
options: They shall remember their evil ways and loathe themselves
They will boast of their past achievements
They will forget their sins and continue as before
They will blame others for their downfall
questions.correctAnswer: They shall remember their evil ways and loathe themselves
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:31 states Israel will remember their evil ways and loathe themselves for their iniquities and abominations, indicating true repentance and conviction (cf. Psalm 51:3-4; Jeremiah 3:22; 2 Corinthians 7:10; Revelation 3:19).
